articles.headline: Iran’s President Vows to Ignore U.N. Measures
articles.snippet: Mahmoud Ahmadinejad said that he considered the dispute over his country’s nuclear program “closed.”
articles.abstract: Mahmoud Ahmadinejad said that he considered the dispute over his country’s nuclear program “closed.”
articles.lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 25 — Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, the president of Iran, said Tuesday that he considered the dispute over his country’s nuclear program “closed” and that Iran would disregard the resolutions of the Security Council, which he said was dominated by “arrogant powers.”

articles.headline: For Gaza’s Young at Play, Fields Can Be Deadly
articles.snippet: Since June 1, 18 Palestinians in Gaza under 19 have died from Israeli fire, a group that monitors the figures said.
articles.abstract: Since June 1, 18 Palestinians in Gaza under 19 have died from Israeli fire, a group that monitors the figures said.
articles.lead_paragraph: GAZA — The three Abu Ghazala fathers were in mourning, in the Palestinian way, sitting with their relatives recently in a shaded courtyard, open to the fields of watermelon and eggplant in which their children had died.

articles.headline: At 9 Wednesday, in One Ring, 3 Contenders
articles.snippet: The three new television series that ranked highest in a closely watched industry survey are facing off: “Kitchen Nightmares” on Fox, “Private Practice” on ABC and “Bionic Woman” on NBC.
articles.abstract: The three new television series that ranked highest in a closely watched industry survey are facing off: “Kitchen Nightmares” on Fox, “Private Practice” on ABC and “Bionic Woman” on NBC.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the most eagerly anticipated showdown of the fall television season, the three new series that ranked highest in a closely watched industry survey are facing off tonight  all at 9 p.m. Eastern time.

articles.headline: Reborn in the U.S.A.
articles.snippet: A wave of luxury jeans makers rises from the ruins  of an industry in Los Angeles.
articles.abstract: A wave of luxury jeans makers rises from the ruins  of an industry in Los Angeles.

articles.headline: Halo 3 Arrives, Rewarding Gamers, and Microsoft
articles.snippet: Microsoft hopes that the new version of Halo, which is exclusive to the Xbox 360, will persuade more consumers to choose its game machine over others.
articles.abstract: Microsoft hopes that the new version of Halo, which is exclusive to the Xbox 360, will persuade more consumers to choose its game machine over others.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bill Gates, the chairman of Microsoft, is the richest man on earth. R. J. Bollard, a freshman at the University of Washington, said he would have 73 cents left in his bank account as of midnight. And that’s one reason Mr. Gates is likely to be the richest man on earth for quite a while.

articles.headline: Inspector Finds Broad Failures in Oil Program
articles.snippet: The federal agency that collects royalties from oil and gas companies is plagued with ethical lapses, a report says.
articles.abstract: The federal agency that collects royalties from oil and gas companies is plagued with ethical lapses, a report says.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 — The Interior Department’s program to collect billions of dollars annually from oil and gas companies that drill on federal lands is troubled by mismanagement, ethical lapses and fears of retaliation against whistle-blowers, the department’s chief independent investigator has concluded.

articles.headline: G.M. and Union Keep Talks Alive
articles.snippet: It appeared the two sides were making progress as, in an unusual move, they continued to bargain into the early-morning hours.
articles.abstract: It appeared the two sides were making progress as, in an unusual move, they continued to bargain into the early-morning hours.
articles.lead_paragraph: Who will blink first: General Motors or the United Automobile Workers?

articles.headline: Sunni Insurgents in New Campaign to Kill Officials
articles.snippet: Sunni Arab extremists have begun a systematic campaign to assassinate police chiefs, police officers, other Interior Ministry officials and tribal leaders throughout Iraq.
articles.abstract: Sunni Arab extremists have begun a systematic campaign to assassinate police chiefs, police officers, other Interior Ministry officials and tribal leaders throughout Iraq.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Sept. 25 — Sunni Arab extremists have begun a systematic campaign to assassinate police chiefs, police officers, other Interior Ministry officials and tribal leaders throughout Iraq, staging at least 10 attacks in 48 hours.

articles.headline: He’s Happier, She’s Less So
articles.snippet: Two new research papers offer evidence that there is  a growing happiness gap between men and women.
articles.abstract: Two new research papers offer evidence that there is  a growing happiness gap between men and women.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last year, a team of researchers added a novel twist to something known as a time-use survey. Instead of simply asking people what they had done over the course of their day, as pollsters have been doing since the 1960s, the researchers also asked how people felt during each activity. Were they happy? Interested? Tired? Stressed?

articles.headline: No Limit for Waits on Runways
articles.snippet: Airlines still have not agreed on how many hours confined passengers would have to wait before they can demand to be released from a plane.
articles.abstract: Airlines still have not agreed on how many hours confined passengers would have to wait before they can demand to be released from a plane.
articles.lead_paragraph: Months after thousands of passengers were stranded for hours on airport runways last winter, airlines still have not agreed on how many hours confined passengers would have to wait before they can demand to be released from a plane, the Transportation Department’s inspector general has found.
